editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: OF QVENCHING, AND NOT QVENCHING OF THE SPIRIT
div.p:
IN the 16. VerÅ¿. the ApoÅ¿tle had exhorted the TheÅ¿Å¿alonians to rejoyce evermore. That is, that they Å¿hould carry themÅ¿elves Å¿o holily, & circumÅ¿pectly, they Å¿hould walke Å¿o cloÅ¿ely with God, that they might have continuall joy in the Holy GhoÅ¿t from the Å¿ence of Gods love,
and favour. For it is a Å¿ure thing that a ChriÅ¿tian Å¿o demeaning himÅ¿elfe as his rule guides him, may live the moÅ¿t comfortable life of any man in the world. He may keepe a continuall feaÅ¿t, and a feaÅ¿t is made for laughter, Eccl. 10. Dayes of feaÅ¿ting are dayes of joy; and Å¿o a ChriÅ¿tian may make all his dayes feÅ¿tivall, and joyfull like the dayes of the Jewes Purim, EÅ¿ter 9. dayes of feaÅ¿ting and of joy.

If it be not Å¿o with a ChriÅ¿tian, it is moÅ¿t what his owne fault, and comes from Å¿ome fayling and miÅ¿carriage in himÅ¿elfe, that hee doth not that which he Å¿hould, to maintaine his heart in this happie frame. The ApoÅ¿tle therefore having adviÅ¿ed hereto he layes downe Å¿ome rules and meanes in certaine precepts, for the procuring and preÅ¿erving of this Å¿pirituall joy.

1. The FirÅ¿t Precept, verÅ¿. 17. pray continually. He that would rejoyce continually, muÅ¿t pray continually, he that would rejoyce evermore, muÅ¿t pray evermore. As is our conÅ¿cience of, and conÅ¿tancy in the duty of prayer: Å¿uch is the conÅ¿tancie
of our joy. Prayer neglected, intermitted brings an Eclips, & an IntermiÅ¿Å¿ion, and Interruption of our joy. Seldome praying, and conÅ¿tant rejoycing will never Å¿tand together.

2. The Å¿econd Precept is this, verÅ¿. 18. In al things give thankes, He that would rejoyce in all eÅ¿tates and conditions muÅ¿t be thankefull in all eÅ¿tates and conditions. He that would rejoyce

ã in non-Latin alphabet ã . The more thankefull wee are to God, the more cauÅ¿e of joy we Å¿hall have in God.

3. The third Precept, is this verÅ¿e 19. Quench not the Å¿pirit. He that would rejoyce evermore muÅ¿t keepe the Å¿pirit unquench'd. The way to keep ones Å¿elf warme, is to keepe the fire burning. It is a fond thing for a man to quench his fire, and then thinke to keepe himÅ¿elfe Å¿till warme. It is no wonder that this man complaines of cold, that hath let his fire goe out, or hath himÅ¿elfe quench'd, and extinguiÅ¿ht it. And thus we have the coherence of theÅ¿e words with the former.

Now for the words, Quench not the Å¿pirit. In them there is a Metaphor, and a Metonymie. The metaphor in the word Quench: Quenching properly is of fire, when the light and heate of fire is abated and put out, wee uÅ¿e to Å¿ay it is quenched. And hence is this word borrowed to Å¿ignifie the abating, decaying, or extinguiÅ¿hing of the Å¿pirit.
The Metonymie is in the word Spirit. Spirit is taken
I. For the eÅ¿Å¿ence of the Deity. So John 4. God is a Spirit. It is not Å¿o taken here.
II. For the third perÅ¿on in the Trinity, the Holy GhoÅ¿t. 1 John 5.7. The Father, the Word, and the holy Spirit. This is not meant here.
III. For the gifts of the Spirit. And thus it is here meant. Quench not the gifts and graces of the Spirit. Now the Spirit, in this Å¿enÅ¿e is taken diverÅ¿ly.

1. FirÅ¿t for the gift of PropheÅ¿ie. 1 Sam. 10.6.10. Then the Spirit of the Lord Å¿hall come upon thee; And the
Å¿pirit of the Lord came upon him, viz. upon Saul.

2. For Gifts and Abilities, to diÅ¿charge any calling, whether it bee extraordinary or heroicall, and this is called the Spirit of fortitude and courage, Judg. 14.6. The Å¿pirit of the Lord came upon SampÅ¿on, Judg. 3.10. Vpon Othniel, and upon Saul againÅ¿t NahaÅ¿h. 1 Sam. 11.6. Or whether it bee ordinary gifts of government by which a man is fitted for MagiÅ¿tracy, 1 Sam. 10.6. or for MiniÅ¿teriall gifts. Or for art and skill in any mechanicall trade, Exod. 31.3. Bezaliel was filled with the Spirit of God to finde out curious workes to worke in gold.

3. For the gifts and common graces of Illumination, as knowledge of the doctrine of religion, underÅ¿tanding of the truthes of the GoÅ¿pel, and other Å¿uch common graces as Reprobates may have. Thus it is taken Heb. 4.6. have taÅ¿ted of the heavenly gift, and made partakers of the holy GhoÅ¿t. That is, if they had their underÅ¿tandings inlightned & their judgemeÌts convinced of the GoÅ¿pel,
if they were inlightned by the work of the Spirit of God.

4. Fourthly, It is taken for the graces of Å¿anctification, for the Å¿anctifying gifts of the Å¿pirit. And therefore it is that the name of the Å¿pirit is given to diverÅ¿e graces, as IÅ¿a. 11.2. The Å¿pirit of meekneÅ¿Å¿e, EpheÅ¿. 1.17. The Å¿pirit of faith, 1 Cor. 4.13. And the Å¿pirit of love, 2 Tim. 1.17. that is, the gift of meekneÅ¿Å¿e, faith, love, infuÅ¿ed by the Holy GhoÅ¿t.
Now concerning theÅ¿e graces of Å¿anctification, we muÅ¿t remember two DiÅ¿tinctions.

DiÅ¿tinct. 1. Some Å¿anctifying graces are radicall, originall, fundamentall graces, primary graces as they may be called, which are the immediate worke of the Å¿pirit, as faith, hope, love: others are Å¿econdary graces iÅ¿Å¿uing and flowing from theÅ¿e, which though the Spirit workes too, yet it workes by theÅ¿e: Å¿uch is joy which ariÅ¿es from faith, Rom. 14. There is a difference between the coales of fire that lye on the harth, and the flame of the fire which is kindled from the coals on the harth. When a mans faith cauÅ¿es joy, then faith flames; when his hope breedes confidence, then hope flames; and when a mans love makes him zealous, then his love flames, and burnes out. So when a mans conÅ¿cience is in trouble, and diÅ¿quiet, a man may uÅ¿e playÅ¿ters of eaÅ¿e, may Å¿eeke to quiet his Å¿pirit with merry company, good fellowÅ¿hip, following his pleaÅ¿ures, following his buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, hee may be padling with theÅ¿e playÅ¿ters and poulteyÅ¿es that men in the world Å¿eeke eaÅ¿e by; but yet Å¿o long as the thorne is in the heart, Å¿o long as guilt is in the conÅ¿cience, all theÅ¿e Å¿labberments will never eaÅ¿e the paine. PÅ¿alme 38.3. THE Prophet complaines verÅ¿. 10. of the courÅ¿e entertainment that he had amongÅ¿t the people; that hee was a man of contention to the whole earth, hee was counted a contentious fellow, and Å¿o hated and

div.p:
It is the duty of every one to uÅ¿e all meanes and diligence to get the truth, to be willing to be at the coÅ¿t of all paines and diligence for the buying and compaÅ¿Å¿ing the truth, wiÅ¿dome, godlineÅ¿Å¿e, &c.
